title.narrative: Complementary WASH Emergency Response for IDPs Camps in Idleb Governorate

description.narrative:
The project interventions are specifically designed to address the Strategic and Cluster Objectives as outlined in the STHF 2020 Allocation Paper, making use of the resources amp expertise, of IHR and their geographic access to the targeted sites in Idleb. The selected population has been targeted in accordance with Severity Indexing provided by the WASH Cluster, which is aimed at ensuring those who are most in need of life-saving assistance are prioritized under this Intervention. IHR will provide 28,164 IDP's living in 16 settlements and camps in Idleb governorate with basic WASH services, adequate drinking water via water trucking (35 liter per capita per day) while constantly assuring the quality of the water through chlorination and tested, solid waste removal, rubbish bins, storage water tank, desludging latrine septic tanks, address the gap in latrines numbers in the targeted camps by construction 33 new latrines block and making them gender-sensitive and to address the needs of elderly and disabled beneficiaries, additional consumable hygiene kits will be distributed to displaced families in targeted camps, as well as providing the necessary tools for having more clean environment, distribution for motivating personal hygiene items and promoting hygiene awareness sessions in order to increase the awareness level of the population in the targeted camps to prevent the spread of COVID19 and all will be implemented and provided according to the SPHERE and Syrian standards. The intervention will include provision of the operational cost (fuel, oil, chlorine, and salaries) in Al Omah water station that will support IDP’s in targeted camps to obtain clean and adequate water for drinking and personal hygiene. The supporting of this water station will also result in reducing pressure on the private water vendors and help dependent people to receive water through water-trucking at affordable cost with adequate quantity.
Finally, rehabilitation of the sewage systems in Al Nahda camp that is gradually deteriorating due to damage and lack of maintenance, these networks suffer from partial destruction, which is resulted in sewage water leaks through cracks under the ground, which affects the drinkable water.
IHR will hire female staff in distribution and monitoring teams to facilitate communication and consultation between IHR staff and women and girls. IHR will hire women and men and will provide them with cleaning tools and materials to clean latrines in the targeted camps to sustain those latrines and keep them clean for use by the whole camps.
With the support of OCHA, IHR will ensure the continuation of basic services whilst also increasing access (increase quantity) and quality (meeting Sphere standards) of essential WASH services. Increased focus will be placed on ensuring displaced people have access to appropriate sanitation facilities, the Protection concerns of women and girls are considered, and environmental health and hygiene promotion are enhanced.
